case_name: Kanwal Ram & Ors. v. Sadh Ram

facts.text: This is Criminal Appeal No. 167 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 167 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 31, 1963, of the Judicial Commissioners Court Himachal Pradesh, in Criminal Appeal No. 7 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 31, 1963, of the Judicial Commissioners Court Himachal Pradesh, in Criminal Appeal No. 7 of 1963.

facts.text: The appeal arises out of a conviction for bigamy and for the abetment of it under ss. 494 and 109 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a companyviction for bigamy and for the abetment of it under ss. 194 and 109 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: The trial Court acquitted the accused persons.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court acquitted the accused persons but on appeal the Judicial Commissioner of Himachal Pradesh companyvicted them.

facts.text: On appeal the Judicial Commissioner of Himachal Pradesh convicted the accused.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court acquitted the accused persons but on appeal the Judicial Commissioner of Himachal Pradesh companyvicted them. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: Originally four persons were charged: Kubja the bride, Kanwal Ram the bridegroom, Hira Nand and Seesia both relations of the bride.

anchor.surface_text: Originally four persons were charged, namely, Kubja the bride, Kanwal Ram the bride-room, Hira Nand and Seesia both relations of the bride,

facts.text: Hira Nand and Seesia charged under s. 494 read with s. 109 for abetment of bigamy by Kubja and Kanwal Ram.

anchor.surface_text: the latter two having been charged under s. 494 read with s. 109 for abetment of the offence of bigamy companymitted by the two first mentioned accused.

facts.text: Charges framed on the complaint of Sadh Ram to whom Kubja had been earlier married.

anchor.surface_text: The charges were framed on the companyplaint of Sadh Ram to whom Kubja had been earlier married.

facts.text: Sadh Ram implicated Hiroo, the mother of Kubja, but she was discharged by the magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant had also implicated Hiroo, the mother of Kubja but she was discharged by the magistrate.

facts.text: Hira Nand died pending the appeal in this Court.

anchor.surface_text: Hira Nand died pending the appeal in this Court.

facts.text: Sadh Ram was married to Kubja sometime in 1940-41.

anchor.surface_text: Sadh Ram was married to Kubja sometime in 1940-41.

facts.text: The marriage between Kanwal Ram and Kubja took place in September 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The marriage between the appellant Kanwal Ram and Kubja is said to have taken place in September 1955.

facts.text: By September 1955 the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 had come into force prohibiting marriage of a Hindu during lifetime of spouse.

anchor.surface_text: By this time the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 had companye into force and it prohibited the marriage of a Hindu during the lifetime of his or her spouse.

facts.text: Parties belong to a village in Himachal Pradesh among whom customary Praina marriage is recognised.

anchor.surface_text: The parties belong to a village in Himachal Pradesh among whom a customary form of marriage called Praina, is recognised.

facts.text: Both marriages were performed according to Praina form.

anchor.surface_text: Both the marriages were performed according to that form.

facts.text: Marriage of Kubja with Sadh Ram though originally challenged is now accepted.

anchor.surface_text: The marriage of Kubja with Sadh Ram though originally challenged is number accepted.

facts.text: The only question is whether the second marriage between Kubja and Kanwal Ram has been proved.

anchor.surface_text: The only question is whether the second marriage of Kubja, that is to say, between Kubja and Kanwal Ram, has been proved.

facts.text: Sadh Ram admitted that puja at the entrance and bowing at the hearth by the bride after picking up the pot were compulsory ceremonies and if not performed marriage not complete.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplaint Sadh Ram himself admitted that puja at the entrance and bowing at the hearth by the bride after she had picked up the pot were companypulsory ceremonies. He added, If any one of these ceremonies is number performed, then the marriage is number companyplete.

facts.text: The only witness who spoke about the ceremonies at Kubja-Kanwal Ram marriage said Seesia brought suhag and Hira Nand acted as Prainu, no mention of other ceremonies.

anchor.surface_text: Now all that the only witness who spoke about the ceremonies observed at the marriage of Kubja and Kanwal Ram said was that Seesia had brought the suhag and Hira Nand acted as Prainu. He does number mention any of the other ceremonies to which we have earlier referred.

facts.text: Trial Court held essential ceremonies not proved.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Court also took the same view.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner relied on Kanwal Ram's statement of sexual relationship with Kubja to prove marriage.

anchor.surface_text: He first referred to a statement by the appellant Kanwal Rain that he had sexual relationship with Kubja. We are entirely unable to agree that this, even if true, would at all prove his marriage with Kubja.

facts.text: Kubja, Hira Nand and Hiroo filed statement in restitution of conjugal rights application by Sadh Ram stating Kubja married Kanwal Ram after first marriage dissolved.

anchor.surface_text: Then the learned Judicial Commissioner relied on a statement filed by Kubja, Hira Nand and Hiroo in answer to an application for restitution of companyjugal rights filed by Sadh Ram against Kubja and others, in which it was stated that Kubja married Kanwal Ram after her marriage with Sadh Ram had been dissolved.

facts.text: Kanwal Ram and Seesia did not make the statement admitting second marriage.

anchor.surface_text: Now the statement admitting the second marriage by these persons is certainly number evidence of the marriage so far as Kanwal Ram and Seesia are companycerned they did number make it.

facts.text: Court held second marriage not proved as essential ceremonies not shown to have been performed.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended for the appellants that this evidence was number enough to show that the marriage of Kubja and Kanwal Ram can be said to have been performed. We think this companytention is justified.

issues.text: whether the evidence about the marriage ceremonies is enough to show that the marriage of Kubja and Kanwal Ram can be said to have been performed

anchor.surface_text: Now all that the only witness who spoke about the ceremonies observed at the marriage of Kubja and Kanwal Ram said was that Seesia had brought the suhag and Hira Nand acted as Prainu. anchor.surface_text: Then the learned Judicial Commissioner relied on a statement filed by Kubja, Hira Nand and Hiroo in answer to an application for restitution of conjugal rights filed by Sadh Ram against Kubja and others, in which it was stated that Kubja married Kanwal Ram after her marriage with Sadh Ram had been dissolved. Now the statement admitting the second marriage by these persons is certainly not evidence of the marriage so far as Kanwal Ram and Seesia are concerned they did not make it.

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the respondent state drew our attention to R. v. Robinson 1 in support of his contention that it is not necessary to prove that all the ceremonies required for the particular form of marriage had been observed. We do not think the case supports that proposition.

anchor.surface_text: Now the statement admitting the second marriage by these persons is certainly number evidence of the marriage so far as Kanwal Ram and Seesia are companycerned they did number make it. Nor do we think, it is evidence of the marriage even against Kubja. First, treated as an admission, the entire document has to be read as a whole and that would prove the dissolution of the first marriage of Kubja which would make the second marriage innocent. Secondly, it is clear that in law such admission is number evidence of the fact of the second marriage having, taken place.

Miller 4  it has been held that admission of marriage by the accused is number evidence of it for the purpose of proving marriage in an adultry or bigamy case.

holdings.text: We think this contention is justified.

anchor.surface_text: We think this contention is justified. In Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande v. The State of Maharashtra 1 this Court held that a marriage is not proved unless the essential ceremonies required for its solemnisation are proved to have been performed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Only witness mentioned suhag and Prainu but omitted other essential ceremonies like puja, pot picking, bowing; applies Bhaurao precedent requiring proof of essential ceremonies.

holdings.text: a marriage is not proved unless the essential ceremonies required for its solemnisation are proved to have been performed.

anchor.surface_text: In Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande v. The State of Maharashtra 1 this Court held that a marriage is not proved unless the essential ceremonies required for its solemnisation are proved to have been performed. The evidence of the witness called to prove the marriage ceremonies, showed that the essential ceremonies had not been performed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Supreme Court precedent in Bhaurao; applies to facts where essential Praina ceremonies not evidenced.

holdings.text: So that evidence cannot justify the conviction.

anchor.surface_text: The evidence of the witness called to prove the marriage ceremonies, showed that the essential ceremonies had not been performed. So that evidence cannot justify the convic- tion. The trial Court also took the same view.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ceremony evidence fails to prove essential rites; trial court acquittal correct.

holdings.text: In a bigamy case, the second marriage as a fact, that is to say, the ceremonies constituting it, must be proved.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cites precedents (Pitambur, Kallu, Archbold, Morris v. Miller) that admissions insufficient in bigamy; ceremonies fact must be independently proved.

holdings.text: We are unable, therefore, to think that the written statement of Kubja affords any assistance towards proving her marriage with Kanwal Ram.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes R v Robinson, which concerned residency formality not ceremonies; all essential ceremonies required.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended for the appellants that this evidence was number enough to show that the marriage of Kubja and Kanwal Ram can be said to have been performed. The evidence of the witness called to prove the marriage ceremonies, showed that the essential ceremonies had number been performed. So that evidence cannot justify the companyvic- tion.
